thesis.description: Measurements have been made to determine if the amount of dimethylether sorbed on alumina, under the same conditions of temperature and bulk phase density, depends upon its thermal history. It would be expected on the basis of the orientation hypothesis that the sorption would "be changed by destroying the residual liquid structure which persists above the critical temperature. Within the limits of experimental error, however, no difference could be detected. The variation of sensitivity of quartz spirals used for weighing has been investigated, and an equation has been deduced for making suitable corrections. It was also found that the sensitivity varies with the weight suspended on the spiral, but to a much smaller extent. Measurements made with several spirals having different sensitivities indicated that the correction factors are practically independent of the sensitivity within limits, and that the average value of these constants may be used with a considerable degree of accuracy. (...)
thesis.creator: Broughton, James William
thesis.subject: Chemistry
thesis.title: Sorption and heat measurements near the critical temperature; a correction equation for the quartz spring balance.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: En France nous avons tendance à croire %ue les Canadiens français se souviennent avec amour, de leur ancienne patrie.N'ont-ils pas adopté pour devise: Je me souviens? Plusieurs conférenciers et hommes de lettres français ont fait s'accréditercette légende, soit en cachant consciemment la vérité, soit en ne racontant inconsciemment que ce qu'ils ont vu envoyageant, c'est-à-dire le côté romanesque des choses. Un Français ne peut conserver longtemps d'illusion lorsqu'il habiteparmi les Canadiens. Il est à remarquer que, Même avant 1763, des .français avaient senti comme une barrière s'éleverentre la nouvelle et la vieille France. Bougainville écrivait en 1758: "... il semble que nous soyons d'une nationdifférente, ennemie même." Aujourd'hui, c'est un peu la même impression qui reste, disons-le franchement.Cependant, lorsque nous vivons au milieu d'eux et que nous prenons une part active à leurs joies et à leurs peinesles qualités françaises des Canadiens se révèlent à nos yeux et nous disons: "Ces gens-là sont Français, aussi Françaisque nous." Quelle est donc cette barrière qui semble séparer les Français et les Canadiens-français intellectuellement?Essayons de comprendre quels sont ces malentendus qui les séparent. Cette thèse montrera que des fautes ont été commisesde part et d'autre, comme dans toutes les querelles de famille. [...]
thesis.creator: Bronner, Frédéric Jean Lionel
thesis.subject: Nationalism -- France.
French-Canadians.
Nationalism -- Québec (Province)
Canada -- History -- To 1763 (New France)
Biculturalism -- Canada.
thesis.title: La survivance française.

thesis.description: Two samples of high sulfur organic soils from the Province of Quebec were investigated as to the nature of their sulfur content.It was found that over 98 percent of the sulfur was organic in nature and that only a small amount of inorganic sulfur was present as very little was removed byelectrodialysis or by the solvent action of water or dilute acid. No attempt was made to isolate any organic sulfur-containingcompound as the purpose of this investigation was to determine if the sulfur bears any definite relation to phosphorus or nitrogen.Since no evidence could be obtained of the existence of protein sulfur in the muck soil, it was concluded that the sulfur was not present as organic protein sulfur,and is therefore different from nitrogen in this respect. Sulfur has been shown to be different from phosphorus in that no sulfuric acid is split off on acid hydrolysis,showing the absence of an ester-like linkage, and that sulfur is present in the humic acid obtained by acidificationof the dilute alkaline extract of the muck soil. Evidence has been presented to arhow that the sulfur is very closely related to the lignin-like complexof the muck soil, and since the lignin is the substance most resistant to decomposition in the soil, this mayaccount for the much higher content of sulfur in organic as compared with inorganic soils.
thesis.creator: Boone, Charles Sheldon
thesis.subject: Agricultural Chemistry
thesis.title: A study of the nature of the sulphur compounds in a Quebec peat soil.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Quebec celery growers have always experienced considerable difficulty in keeping their produce for any length of time incold storage. At the best, celery growing and subsequent storage have been considered somewhat of a gamble. Growershave found that the storage life of celery varies from year to year, depending on climatic and cultural conditions duringgrowth, and upon other factors entering into the harvesting and storage of this commodity. They have also found that certainvarieties will keep better than others, and that celery from some localities will keep better than celery from others. Adifference in keeping quality has also been found with celery from different parts of the same field.
thesis.creator: Ayers, George Wilfred.
thesis.subject: Plant Pathology
thesis.title: Studies on celery storage disorders.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The critical study of the history of Canadian political parties is comparatively new. Until the publication of Dr. Frank Underhill's provocativemonograph on the development of national parties some thr~e years 1 ago, the history of Canadian parties had appeared only as an incidentalin the biography of some public man. Joseph Pope sketched, with the broadest of strokes, the Conservative party in his study of Sir John A. Macdonald.Substantially the same plan was followed by both Dr. Skelton2 and by the late Sir John "v"Jillison3 in their biographies of Sir liilfrid La.urier. Ofpolitical chronicles there were, of course, a great number but they were usually apologetic in tone. 4 Equally cursory have been the referencesmade to Canadian political parties in the standard constitutional histories which have been content to assume rather than to examine. 5 This neglectis a striking commentary on the unwillingness of Canadian scholars to grapple with the fundamentalsof government for, in the parliamentary systemunder which we live, the political party is the driving force of government. While, therefore, a study of the French-Canadian Conservative partymay traverse much of the ground covered in biographies, constitutional histories and so on, it does so with different emphasis and for a differentpurpose. The basis of party in French-Canada lay in the needs and the aspirations of the French-Canadian community. [...]
thesis.creator: Cooper, John Irwin
thesis.subject: History.
thesis.title: French-Canadian conservatism in Principle and in Practice 1873 -- 1891
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: On April lOth, 1848, a meeting of Chartists was advertised to be held on Kennington Common, a large open ground to the south of Westminster Bridge, London. Up to date no accurate critical account of this meeting has appeared in any history, or in any monograph dealing with the year 1848, or with the history of the Chartist movement. The purpose of this essay is to supply this lack. First, however, a few words about what this meeting involved. The Chartist movement had its inception in the year 1837 at a meeting of the Working Men's Association of London, to which a number of Radical members of Parliament had been invited. [...]
thesis.creator: Self, George M.
thesis.subject: History.
thesis.title: The Chartist incident of Kennington Common, April 10th, 1848 : critically examined, more particularly in the light of the Home office papers at the Public Records office, London.

thesis.description: Beauchastel Township is west of the Township of Rouyn, and occupies an important position on the axis of the well-recognized zone of weakness along which mineral deposits occur, and which passes through Kirkland Lake and Noranda, and thence eastward in the Province of Quebec. The region was prospected and developed at the time of the discovery of gold and copper at Noranda, and though its history has not been as bright as that of the neighbouring township, a number of deposits of economic value have been operated. [...]

thesis.title: The geology of a section of Beauchastel township, Que.

thesis.description: For many years the existence in wood of a chemically combined lignin-carbohydrate complex has been suspected. As early as 1866 Erdmann (1) pointed out the possible existence of a chemical union between the various components of the cell wall. He had been impressed particularly with the difference between pure cotton cellulose and the cellulosic material in the wood. Erdmann placed much weight in the formulation of his compound hypothesis on the fact that the wood was highly insoluble in Schweizer's reagent. It strengthened his conviction that uncombined cellulose was not present in wood. [...]
thesis.creator: Lieff, Morris.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The structure of lignin and its relation to other plant constituents.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Data are herein reported upon the intra-seasonal changes in the nutritive value of a mixed herbage consisting of Kentucky blue grass, red top and wild wb1te clover as shown by growth and digestibility studies with young rabbits. A progressive decline in nutritive value and digestibility until midsummer and a complete recovery in all respects in the fall was noted. These data would indicate that marked differences in nutritive value may exist between herbage representing only ten days growth when taken at different parts of the season. The effect of small increases in lignin upon the digestibility of the various food fractions would indicate that it is not only the amount, but also the mode of deposition of the lignin which determines its effects upon digestibility and nutritive value. The effect of unfavourable growing conditions or approaching maturity would seem to be intimately related to these changes in lignin content.
thesis.creator: Forshaw, Robert P.
thesis.subject: Animal Nutrition and Breeding.
thesis.title: The intra-seasonal changes in the nutritive value of pasture herbage.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: That an obligation rests on public authorities to provide relief assistance for destitute persons has been recognized in Canada for many years. The English Poor Laws served as the model for early colonial legislation dealing with indigency. Following the accepted English practice, the care of destitute persons was a municipal responsibility. The British North America Act placed the legislative powers to deal with indigency within the ambit of provincial rights. All the provinces made provision for the continuation of municipal responsibility for the needy. [...]

thesis.subject: Prairie Provinces -- Economic conditions.
Economics.
Depressions -- 1929 -- Prairie Provinces.
thesis.title: Unemployment relief in the Prairie Provinces, 1930-1937.

thesis.description: Following reports of the cliscovery of gold in the vicinity of Guillet township during the year 1934, the writer was instructed to prepare a report on the mineral possibiities of this new field and to map the gold-bearing formations, particularly to the east of the Gaboury-Blondeau Map-Area, which had been mapped four years before by J. A. Ratty (1). During the course of this work, which was done in the field seasons of 1935 and. 1936, a suite of early Precambrian rocks was found which, due to unusual conditions of regional metamorphism, afforded an opportunity to gather data on features of general intere·st to students of the geology of the Precambrian Shield.[...]

thesis.description: Le thème de la nature n'est pas né au XVIIIe siècle. De tout temps l'homme a ete plus ou moins sensible à l'univers qui l'entoure. Plus il est cultivé. Plus il y voit de mystère, de poésie et de religion. On a vu confirmer cette théorie dans la vie quotidienne. Le sauvage ne s' attache pas aux détails de la nature. au murmure du ruisseau, au bruissement des feuilles, mais tout primitif qu'il soit, il ne demeurera pas insensible devant l'océan en furie. Son âme se soulèvera et voudra se déchaîner comme les elements. [...]

thesis.subject: French fiction -- 18th century -- History and criticism.
Nature in literature.

thesis.description: One of the greatest advances in chemistry in recent years has been the demonstration of the existence of free atoms and radicles as intermediaries in chemical reactions. More and more, reactions which previously were thought to take place through activated molecules directly have been shown on further analysis to depend on preliminary splitting of these molecules into atoms or radicles. Thus there is a peculiar interest in the study of reactions in which a "molecular" mechanism seems of necessity to be involved. Such a reaction is that forming the basis of this present investigation, namely, the reaction between propylene and hydrogen chloride in the liquid state. A further flavor of interest has been added in the facts that the phases studied have been concerned with both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis, and more, that this catalysis has been due to water. Finally, this reaction has played an important part in the development of the theory of discontinuity of state at the critical temperature, and any bearing the results obtained might have on statements previously made in this respect has been a rather important part of the work. [...]
thesis.creator: Brown, Arthur Grambo.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: An investigation of olefine-halogen hydride reactions in the liquid state.

thesis.description: The importance of light in the existence of insect life has been known for many years but it is only within the last three decades that much progress has been made in the study of its effect. About 1890 the study of physiological effects of light was receiving considerable attention, but the apparatus and methods available at that time were soon exhausted, and, for about twenty-five years, the subject was almost forgotten. However, with the discovery of the effects of ultraviolet radiation in biology and the development of various sources of artificial light, together with the improvement of photometric methods, there has developed an increasing interest in the general problem of phototropic responses. [...] Apart from the purely scientific interest of such investigations there is the aspect of practical application. Larger and larger sums are being used every year in the fight to control insects. If some knowledge of the basic responses of insects to various factors in the environment can be accumulated, it is conceivable that more efficient means of control might be devised. With these thoughts in mind, the experiments to be described later were initiated.
thesis.creator: Cameron, James William MacBain.
thesis.subject: Entomology.
thesis.title: The reactions of the housefly, Musca Domestica Linn., to light of different wave-lenghts.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This thesis deals with the general geology in the vicinity of Bralorne Mines, British Columbia. Late Palaezoic and Mesozoic sedimentary and volcanic rocks have been intruded by igneous masses genetically related to the Coast Range Batholith which has given rise to metalliferous deposits. The ore deposits of Bralorne Mines and Pioneer Mines are described particularly with regard to structural features. The vein bearing fissures of these deposits are, believed to be the result of compressive stresses originating southwest of the area. The ore shoots are believed due to various causes, among which the faulted and branched nature of the vein fissures are considered of prime importance. The presence of soda-rich rocks in the vicinity of the ore deposits is stressed, with the belief that such rocks have been developed by changing conditions in the differentiation of a normal magma stem. These conditions have given rise to the albite-rich diorite, the albite granite, related dykes, and subsequently the ore deposits themselves.
thesis.creator: Cleveland, Courtney Ernest.
thesis.subject: Geology.
thesis.title: The geology of the vicinity of Bralorne mines, British Columbia.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: On a beaucoup écrit sur l'influence de seint François de Sales. Un des critiques les plus distingués en a ainsi exprimé son jugement: "De Philothée à la Visitandine de Paray, de Marguerite-Marie à Bernadette de Lourdes, la dévotion de saint François de Sales est aujourd'hui encore la dévotion d'une foule de catholiques français." C'est déjà beaucoup. Mais un autre critique, non moins distingué, va plus loin. "M. Brémond a raison," dit-il, "mais à mon tour, je dirai: il y a plus encore. Non seulement la dévotion, mais l'Eglise entière s'est orientée dans le sens indiqué par saint François de Sales. Les idées dont il était le défenseur lucide et convaincu ont triomphé; et les dogmes, nouvellement définis par l'Eglise au X1Xe siècle, ont été exprimés par lui avec leurs vraies raisons et dans leur vrai sens." (1). Il est encore lu et apprécié dans tous les pays. Ses écrits ont été traduits dans toutes les langues où, dépourvues même de presque tout leur charme et leur force originels, ils continuent à répandre la doctrine et la douceur salésiennes. Il n'est pas difficile de trouver la raison de cette influence permanente de saint François de Sales. Il a parlé et il a écrit son âme, âme de génie, qui a transformé en pensée tous les mouvements du coeur chrétien, qu'il savait exprimer d'une manière simple et gracieuse, d'un coeur parlant à un coeur. Voilà son idéal. [...]
thesis.creator: Kelly, Ignatius.
thesis.subject: PREACHING
Francis, de Sales, Saint, 1567-1622.
thesis.title: L’ influence de François de Sales sur la prédication du dix-huitième siècle.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The problem is concerned with the infestation of coniferous logs by barkbeetles and wood-boring insects during the first season following the felling of the tree. The meristem and wood insects concerned in this study were all members of the order Coleoptera, families Cerambycidae (roundheaded borers), Buprestidae (flatheaded borers), Scolytidae(barkbeetles and ambrosia beetles), and Curculionidae (weevils). The coniferous logs under consideration were cut from tree species of pine, spruce, balsam, and hemlock, all found in Eastern Canada. The present study considers the attractiveness of such logs to oviposition by the barkbeetles and woodborers as influenced by a number of factors enumerated below. Furthermore it investigates the effect of some of these factors upon the subsequent development of these insects after establishment. Of necessity, such a field experiment can only indicate a number of trends but since most of the operating factors cannot be considered independently with any accuracy, the writer believes that an extensive rather than an intensive survey is all that is justified at present. [...]
thesis.creator: Morley, Peter Malcolmson.
thesis.subject: Entomology.
thesis.title: Factors influencing the attractiveness of logs to oviposition by barkbeetles and woodborers.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The present study is the first installment of a work in which I hope eventually to recount the history ot the French fur trade. While the period under consideration at present is preliminary to the tremendous development of the years following 1660, it is of obvious importance to the story as a whole and the scarcity of reliable source material is regrettable. My research has been confined to sources available in Canada, but I am led to believe that there remains little of importance in France concerning this period which may not be seen in transcript at the Public Archives, Ottawa. Consequently it is unlikely that existing material would necessitate any substantial revision in the conclusions arrived at; though the discovery of new sources, such as for instance the records of the Company of New France, would clear up many points that are now obscure. Let us hope such a discovery will soon be made. [...]
thesis.creator: Munroe, David C.
thesis.subject: History.
thesis.title: The fur trade of New France, down to 1663.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: In 1933 F. A. Gibbs, by his description of a thermoelectric blood flow recorder of small bulk and simple construction, enormously expanded the application of the well known physical principle of the thermocouple to physiological research. Since its introduction, and that of the somewhat similar invention of Schmidt, the instrument has been of especial·value in problems relating to the cerebral circulation. Much of the work, such as that of Lennox and Gibbs (1933, 1934, 1935), is based on qualitative estimations of variations in the total blood flow through the brain. The thermocouiple has been put to a yet more interesting use in the detection of focal changes in flow, which use is exemplified by the work of Schmidt, and, at the Montreal Neurological Institute, by that of Norcross, Penfield and Erickson in animals and Penfield in human patients during operative procedures. [...] It will be seen that the problem is twofold and I have analysed the experimental findings under two main heads - the nature of the activity responsible for the circulatory changes, and the cortico-subcortical connections as revealed by the method. During the course of the work facts bearing on the problems of the central vasomotor tracts came to light and have been included, together with observations on autonomic functions recorded on several occasions. [...]
thesis.creator: Nichols, Walter M.
thesis.subject: Neurology.
thesis.title: Changes in the circulation of the brain and spinal cord associated with nervous activity.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: When the twentieth century comes to be reviewed a hundred years hence, one of the most noteworthy characteristics will, without doubt, be the extraordinary fruitfulness which the thought of evolution has enjoyed in this century. As we write, it is a record of fact that, while in biological circles there are explanations of the evolutionary process other than that of "Natural Selection" as suggested by Darwin, yet the theory of evolution has met with such universal acceptance that it is now taken for granted; not only does it provide a background for biological thought, but it has given a method - and in many cases a terminology - to the study of origins and developments in many diverse realms of thought. Even the critics of Darwin have become his beneficiaries; nowhere is this more clearly seen than amongst theologians from whose number came many sharp criticisms of Darwin, both in the years immediately following and for some years after the publication of "Origin of Species" and "Descent of Man". Today, theologians make use of the thought of evolution in their treatment of comparative religions, showing Christianity as the goal of the evolutionary process in religious development, as well as making use of the concept in other branches of theological study. [...]
thesis.creator: Reed, Ernest Samuel.
thesis.subject: ETHICS
Hume, David, 1711-1776.
thesis.title: A criticism of the naturalistic ethics of Hume.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This study was originally planned in an attempt to explain the mechanism involved in fixed dilatation of the pupil resulting from ipsilateral cerebral compression. It soon became evident, however, that the pupillary changes constituted but one element of complete oculomotor nerve palsy. An investigation has been made of eleven clinical cases, seven of whom failed to recover and were examined at necropsy, and of fifteen experimental procedures carried out on Macacus Rhesus monkeys. Each clinical case examined at necropsy and each successful experimental animal showed signs of ipsilateral third nerve palsy, and in each there was found a herniation of the ipsilateral hippocampal gyrus over the free edge of the tentorium cerebelli pressing on the third nerve. As the work progressed it became evident that there were two other features sometimes associated with ipsilateral third nerve signs and herniation of the hippocampal gyrus. These were ipsilateral hemiplegia and infarction of the occipital lobes. The former was present in one clinical case and in two of the experimental animals. The latter was discovered at necropsy in four patients but it was not found in any of the experimental animals. Both these features have already been described in the literature, and although not entirely original as far as this work is concerned, it has been considered fitting to include them in this report [...]
thesis.creator: Reid, William L.
thesis.subject: Neurology.
thesis.title: The physiology and pathology of herniation of the cerebrum through the incisura tentorii.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The purpose of this thesis is to describe the Geology of the Orland Gold Mines property as far as it can be worked out from the information collected by the author in the field during the summer of 1937 and from additional information from diamond drilling carried on during the winter. [Location and Accessibility]The Orland Gold Mines property is located two miles southeast of Aldennac Siding and south of the main line of Nipissing Central railroad. La Mine D'Or Champlain Ltée property lies to the west and the Adeline Lake and Kekeko properties to the east. The Orland group consists of six claims situated in lots 27 to 40 range 4 and seven claims lots 34 to 40 range 5. The property is accessible by means of the Hasamac wagon road which crosses the property. [Method of Investigation]A detailed geological map was made on the scale of 200' to the inch. The townships had been divided into strips or ranges one mile wide running east and west. From these north south picket lines were cut out at intervals of 858', which were chained consistently in the north to south direction and staked every two hundred feet. Outcrops were located by the pace and compass method using these lines as controls. While the mapping was in progress, stripping, trenching and test pitting were carried on in an effort to locate ore deposits. This was partly supervised by the author. Fourteen holes were drilled later at various points to test certain sections where evidence of mineralization was found.[...]
thesis.creator: Robinson, Raymond Francis.
thesis.subject: Geology.
thesis.title: The geology of the Orland property, Beauchastel township, Province of Quebec.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The kinetics of a chemical reaction can best be studied by the rates of reaction and the various influences of temperature and pressure on these rates. Gaseous reactions are best suited for such a study, as the kinetic theory best describes the behaviour of gases. Ordinary considerations of chemical reactions, as shown by the reaction formula, do no more than consider the reactants and products and give no hint as to the mechanism. Clues to mechanisms come from a study of the kinetics, i.e. by a study of the reaction velocity and the application of certain well known relationships, which tell accurately the number of molecules entering into the reaction. In general, reactions can be classified into unimolecular and dimolecular reactions; the supposedly multimolecular reactions can be shown to consist of a series of rapid unimolecular and/or dimolecular steps. A few tarmolecular reactions are known, but these are exceptions. [...]
thesis.creator: Shane, Gerald.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The kinetics of polymerization of isobutene.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: A fundamental problem in the theory of numbers is that of finding what numbers are represented in ternary quadratic forms. It was found, in many cases, that the numbers not represented followed some simple law so that, although a certain form failed to represent an infinite number of integers, these integers could be determined by a definite set of formulae. It is easy to see that no number of the form 4^h(8n+7), where h and n are integers >= 0, is a sum of three squares. Legendre proved, conversely, in 1798, that all positive integers not of the form 4^h(8n+7), are sums of three squares, i.e. if N if W <> 4^h(8n+7), h, n >= 0, then N = x^2 + y^2 + z^2 where x, y, z are integers. [...]
thesis.creator: Solin, Cecil David.
thesis.subject: ALGEBRA, MODERN
NUMBERS, THEORY OF
thesis.title: Representation of numbers in certain regular and irregular ternary quadratic forms.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This thesis is an attempt to outline the policies and practices of a leading Canadian industrial company in its relations with its employees. Owing to the nature of the subject the identity of the Company is not revealed. The Company is, however, sufficiently representative to afford a general view of progressive industrial policy in employer-employee relationships, although it is perhaps more "typical" of Canadian industry as a whole by its non-recognition of collective bargaining. [...]

Industrial relations -- Canada.
COOPERATION

thesis.title: Industrial relations of a typical Canadian company.
